article.title: Shielding Europe‚Äôs electrical and power systems
article.teaser: Electrical systems are vulnerable to cyberattacks. A new defence system will ensure critical infrastructure keeps running.

section.sectionBody:
Europe‚Äôs Electrical Power and Energy System (EPES) is one of the most complex cyber-physical systems in the world. Any attacks bringing down this critical infrastructure could have a vast cascading effect on others, including water supply, communications, transportation, industry and finance.
‚ÄúEurope has already experienced significant complex cyberattacks and these attacks are increasing,‚Äù says Ghasan Bhatti, project director at https://www.capgemini.com/ (Capgemini) and https://phoenix-h2020.eu/ (PHOENIX) project coordinator. ‚ÄúEven simple attacks can be extremely crucial.‚Äù
In the EU-funded PHOENIX project, researchers developed a cyber-shield security platform for European EPES infrastructure, enabling it to detect and survive large-scale, combined https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/787011 (cyber) and privacy attacks at a reasonable cost.
The PHOENIX consortium was made up of 25 partners spanning the range of required expertise in the EPES cybersecurity field, including energy generation, technology providers, retailers and SMEs. Through five large-scale international pilots, the project assessed all of its developments in real-world scenarios.

section.sectionTitle: Innovating and coordinating Europe‚Äôs cyber defences
section.sectionBody:
The PHOENIX project had three major goals. The first was to strengthen EPES cyber defence by designing novel protective concepts for resilience, survivability, self-healing and accountability to be used within Europe‚Äôs infrastructure.
The PHOENIX team also innovated on existing systems, adapting, upgrading and integrating a number of tools and validating them in large-scale pilots.
The second goal was to improve coordination between European EPES cyber incident discovery, response and recovery. To do this, PHOENIX members created a fully decentralised cybersecurity information awareness platform for authorised stakeholders across Europe.
The third initiative was to accelerate research and innovation within EPES cybersecurity. The PHOENIX team established a series of certification methods and procedures through a newly created Cybersecurity Certification Centre.

The PHOENIX security platform monitors for new incidents, and identifies and mitigates against attacks. PHOENIX generated increased awareness of cyberattacks among stakeholders in European EPES, which resulted in fewer service disruptions due to incidents being detected earlier.
‚ÄúThe PHOENIX project developed an ‚ÄòIncidents‚Äô Information Sharing Platform‚Äô (I2SP), which allows relevant stakeholders to coordinate, share knowledge of and even advance warnings, complying with the European Commission‚Äôs strategy on tackling the rising number of serious cyber incidents,‚Äù explains Bhatti.
Other tools developed during the project include the ‚ÄòSecure, Persistent Communications (SPC)‚Äô platform, a cloud-based communications layer which ensures all data are legitimate and secured.
The Privacy Protection Enforcement (PPE) toolkit uses consent-based approaches to evaluate and mitigate risks associated with identified attacks.

The PHOENIX project has a good sustainability plan where all partners are committed to exploiting the PHOENIX outcomes, notes Bhatti.
‚ÄúSome developments from the PHOENIX project will be available as open-source,‚Äù he adds.
The PHOENIX partners also founded the https://cyberseas.eu/cyberepes-the-cybersecurity-innovation-cluster-for-epes/ (CyberEPES cluster), a collaborative information-sharing project working under the supervision of the European Commission, which aims to improve EPES cybersecurity in Europe.
The PHOENIX team developed 14 policy options ‚Äì along with 10 major privacy, ethics and security concerns and challenges ‚Äì based on lessons drawn from the project, which aim to feed into a wider European strategy for cyber defence.
‚ÄúThese policy options were a major part of the discussion among the multidisciplinary pool of experts and other projects working in the domain of EPES cybersecurity during the Final workshop of the PHOENIX project,‚Äù says Bhatti.

article.keywords: PHOENIX, cyber, security, threat, electrical, power, systems, shield, awareness, policy

article.title: Could hackers really take down the power grid?
article.teaser: High-tech criminals wreaking havoc on critical infrastructure is a staple of Hollywood thrillers ‚Äì but how realistic is this threat? We ask cybersecurity expert Ghasan Bhatti.

project.teaser: PHOENIX aims to offer a cyber-shield armour to European EPES infrastructure enabling cooperative detection of large scale, cyber-human security and privacy incidents and attacks, guarantee the continuity of operations and minimize cascading effects in the infrastructure...

article.title: Sweeteners ‚Äì friend or foe?
article.teaser: Our consumption of sugar remains stubbornly high, far surpassing the World Health Organization‚Äôs suggested level. Can sweeteners help people switch to low-sugar alternatives?

section.sectionBody:
Given the contribution of dietary sugar to the development of obesity and cardio-metabolic disease, the World Health Organization has https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/librariesprovider2/euro-health-topics/obesity/sugars-factsheet.pdf?sfvrsn=d5b89d5f_3&download=true (recommended) that the intake of free sugars should be no more than 10 % of the total energy intake.
As Jo Harrold, one of the coordinators of the https://sweetproject.eu/ (SWEET) project, explains: ‚ÄúArtificial/natural/non-nutritive/lower-calorie sweeteners, along with sweetness enhancers (S&SEs), provide an opportunity to remove calories in the form of sugar, while maintaining the appeal and commercial viability of popular products for the consumer.‚Äù
https://sweetproject.eu/team/dr-jo-harrold (Harrold), dean of Psychology and professor in Appetite and Obesity in the Department of Psychology at the https://www.liverpool.ac.uk/ (University of Liverpool), was keen to identify what the risks and benefits are of using alternative sweeteners. The project also wanted to establish what barriers prevent their use.
‚ÄúAll are approved for human consumption, but S&SEs are currently underutilised because, despite substantial safety data, some studies suggest links to increased risk of stroke and heart disease. Other research suggests they may have a negative impact on gut microbiota,‚Äù she says.

section.sectionTitle: Clinical studies and surveys to establish impact of sugar alternatives
section.sectionBody:
The team used a variety of protocols to study the effect of S&SEs, including acute (1 day) and repeated (14 days) dosing studies focusing on single food items to examine the impact of S&SEs on glycaemic response. They also considered feeding behaviour and blood biochemistry. Trials took place in adults recruited from Denmark, France, Spain and the United Kingdom.
‚ÄúAt the centre of SWEET was the one-year randomised controlled trial (RCT) which investigated whether the prolonged use of S&SEs as part of a healthy, low-sugar diet could improve weight loss maintenance after rapid weight loss,‚Äù adds Harrold.
The RCT considered the benefit-risk markers for Type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases compared to no S&SE consumption. To do so, the trial recruited overweight or obese adults and children from Denmark, Greece, Spain and the Netherlands.
The team also conducted an online survey of over 11 000 consumers in most EU Member States, to examine attitudes, perceptions and behavioural intentions towards S&SEs.

section.sectionTitle: Avoidance of S&SEs mainly driven by perceived risks to health
section.sectionBody:
Analyses indicated that consumers perceived the benefits of S&SEs to include weight loss, diabetes management and oral health. S&SEs from plant-based sources were more positively perceived than those from artificial sources. Avoidance of S&SEs is mainly driven by perceived risks to health.
‚ÄúHowever,‚Äù notes Harrold: ‚ÄúThe short- and medium-term controlled interventions demonstrated that S&SEs in beverages, semi-solid and solid sweet food matrices support lower glycaemic responses, with no adverse impact on appetite, metabolic or health markers either acutely or after two weeks‚Äô repeated daily consumption.‚Äù
The long-term RCT demonstrated not only that replacing sugar in the whole diet with sweeteners improved weight loss control over the long term but importantly, but also that long-term use of sweeteners reduced cravings for sweet foods and did not raise the risks of Type 2 diabetes or cardiovascular disease.
The team produced a decision support tool intended to promote the responsible development and use of sweeteners by industry, which will be accessible via an online interface on the SWEET project‚Äôs website.
‚ÄúWe wanted to facilitate understanding and implementation of the project‚Äôs interventions and outcomes, and foster the adoption of commercial opportunities. This includes https://sweetproject.eu/sweet-project-publications/ (summaries written for non-expert readers),‚Äù Harrold says.

article.keywords: SWEET, S&SEs, sweeteners, sugar alternatives, health, glycaemic response, blood biochemistry, diet

project.teaser: The SWEET project has been designed to i) identify and address the barriers and facilitators to the use of sweeteners and sweetness enhancers (S&SEs) and ii) examine the risks and benefits of using S&SEs to replace sugar in the diet in the contexts of health, obesity, safety...
